content: Hi all, am I missing a lemma that lets you case on whether a list is either the empty list, or formed by concatenation (is of the form c ++ [a])? Essentially the cases version of List.reverseRecOn. I don't need the inductive hypothesis, so it feels like overkill to use List.reverseRecOn
It's very quick to write, but I don't want to duplicate something already in mathlib!
cases l using List.reverseRecOn should work, I think

I guess that gives you the inductive hypothesis anyway, but I think ultimately it's fine to just ignore your feeling of overkill here! In general we don't tend to duplicate custom induction principles for the less general non-inductive cases.
You can also do rcases List.eq_nil_or_concat' l with rfl | ⟨l, b, rfl⟩
Hannah Fechtner has marked this topic as resolved.
that's exactly what I was looking for, thank you!!
Is that preferable to the cases spelling in your opinion, @Yury G. Kudryashov?
